repnme.cdata!:
Jamaica - Financial and Program Management
            Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project's objectives have been
            largely achieved, and some have been exceeded--for example,
            the components of Program Budgeting, Corporate Planning, and
            Customer Service components. Lessons learned or reconfirmed
            include: 1) Achieving institutional changes, such as those
            required for financial management and human resource
            modernization, require a long time horizon to take root and
            yield fruit. This in turn requires a long-term commitment,
            consistency, and continuity of approach and support on the
            part of both the World Bank and the government. 2)
            Comprehensive diagnostic work should be completed during the
            project design to provide a clear basis for implementation
            planning and targeting, to ensure that the proper linkages
            are established among project components, and to help ensure
            that mechanisms are in place to facilitate high level
            government support. 3) Suitable human resource policies and
            mechanisms should be devised to ensure that staff remain in
            positions for which they have been trained for a reasonable
            period; and that the compensation system, at least for
            highly skilled jobs, is such that qualified persons can be
            attracted and retained in public service. 4) Rapid changes
            in information technology necessitate continuous upgrading
            of computer systems. 5) Local ownership of reforms is
            imperative for their success. 6) Finally, institutional
            change is facilitated by early successes and by gaining
            public support.

repnme.cdata!:
Jamaica - Financial and Program Management
            Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the project is to
            support the efforts of the government to improve the
            efficiency of financial and human resources management in
            the Central Administration.  It will provide long- and
            short-term foreign and local consultancies, computer
            hardware and software, office supplies, vehicles, and
            training of local staff in support of four components.
            Under the financial management component, the project will
            assist the government to revise the budget model according
            to program classification, and adapt the present accounting,
            cash management and financial reporting systems to the
            revised budget model.  Under the program management
            component, it will introduce in selected ministries and in
            statutory bodies critical to the functioning of those
            ministries, a corporate planning methodology that will
            assist managers to define the institutions' objectives
            and priorities, identify relevant programs, rationalize the
            relationship between the ministries and key statutory
            bodies, and monitor the progress of program implementation.
            Under the computer component, the project will set up a
            financial management information system to support the
            budgeting, accounting and cash management process in
            selected ministries.  A human resources management
            information system will also be introduced.  A training
            component will provide courses in corporate planning,
            program budgeting, accounting and computer skills.
